fr:title.text: Covers in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Covers in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to B is a cover iff \mathcal {C} satisfies y\colon B|\top \vdash \exists x\colon A.\mkern 5muf(x) = y in its internal language.
Suppose that f is a cover. Let e = (b,a)\colon E\to B \times A be the interpretation of f(x) = y in \mathcal {C}. Note that a is an isomorphism since the following is also an equalizer diagram.
By , {\mathopen {}\llbracket y\colon B.\exists x\colon A.\mkern 5muf(x) = y\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the image of the following composite.
By assumption, fa = b. Thus, the image of b coincides with that of fa.
Since a is an isomorphism, it follows that the image of f is isomorphic to \mathsf {Img}(b). Thus, \mathsf {Img}(b) is an isomorphism.
Assume the converse. Then the identity morphism factors through \mathsf {Img}(b), i.e., \mathsf {Img}(b) is an isomorphism. Thus, it follows that f is a cover.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category. The internal language of \mathcal {C} consists of the signature \Sigma whose sorts are the objects of \mathcal {C}, function symbols are the morphisms of \mathcal {C}, and relation symbols are the subobjects in \mathcal {C}.

We write \mathcal {C} for the canonical \Sigma -structure that maps each variable to the appropriate product projection, each function symbol f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B to its underlying morphism f\colon A_{1} \times \cdots \times A_{n}\to B, and each relation symbol R \rightarrowtail A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} to its underlying subobject R \rightarrowtail A_{1} \times \cdots \times A_{n}.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with sufficient structure and \Gamma = x_{1}\colon B_{1},\ldots ,x_{m}\colon B_{m} be a context over a signature \Sigma . Given a \Sigma -structure M in \mathcal {C}, the interpretation of a formula-in-context \Gamma .\varphi in M is a subobject {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} \rightarrowtail M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) defined recursively on the structure of \varphi as follow:

fr:ul.fr:li: {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \wedge \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the intersection of {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \vee \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the union of {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\lnot \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the Heyting negation of {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\exists x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the image of the following composite: {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma ,x\colon A.\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} \rightarrowtail M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m},A) \xrightarrow {\pi } M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) where \pi is the projection of the first m factors.

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\forall x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is \forall _{\pi }({\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma ,x\colon A.\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M}), where \forall _{\pi } is the right adjoint associated with a Heyting category and \pi \colon M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m},A)\to M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) is the projection of the first m factors.

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\bigvee _{i \in I}\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the arbitrary union of each {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\bigwedge _{i \in I}\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the arbitrary intersection of each {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An epimorphism f\colon A\twoheadrightarrow B is said to be extremal (also called a cover) if for any monomorphism m\colon C\rightarrowtail B and any morphism g\colon A\to C such that f = mg, then m is an isomorphism.

A category \mathcal {C} is said to be regular if it is cartesian, has images, and covers are stable under pullback. A functor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} between regular categories is said to be regular if it is cartesian and preserves covers. Note that since cartesian functors preserve monomorphisms, every regular functor automatically preserves images.

Let F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} be a regular functor and f\colon A\to B be a morphism in \mathcal {C}. By , f admits a cover-mono factorization f = \mathsf {Img}(f)\vartheta _{f}. Then since F preserves monomorphisms and covers, F(\mathsf {Img}(f))F(\vartheta _{f}) forms a cover-mono factorization of F(f). Then by uniqueness, \mathsf {Img}(Ff) \cong F(\mathsf {Img}(f)).

A category \mathcal {C} is said to have images if the inclusion functor \mathsf {Sub}(A) \hookrightarrow {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} admits a left adjoint \mathsf {Img}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}\to \mathsf {Sub}(A) for all objects A \in \mathcal {C}.
